claim: jim clark and richie ginther be the only driver to have both the fastest lap and win the race
resp: Okay, so I need to figure out if the claim is true or false based on the given table. The claim says: "jim clark and richie ginther be the only driver to have both the fastest lap and win the race." First, I should look at each row in the table to see if there are any drivers who both won the race and had the fastest lap. Looking at the first row for Monaco Grand Prix: Jim Clark is the pole position holder, Lorenzo Bandini has the fastest lap, and Jackie Stewart wins. So here, Jim Clark didn't have the fastest lap; it was Lorenzo. Second row is Belgian GP: John Surtees did both pole, fastest lap, and won. So he's one driver who had both. Third row French GP: Lorenzo Bandini did pole and fastest lap, but Jack Brabham wins. Not relevant for Jim or Richie. Fourth row British GP: All three are Jack Brabham, so that's another case where a single driver has both. Fifth Dutch GP: Jack Brabham won, Denny Hulme had the fastest lap. So no. Sixth German GP: Jim Clark is pole, John Surtees fastest lap, and Jack Brabham wins. Not our two. Seventh Italian GP: Mike Parkes pole, Ludovico Scarfiotti both fastest and winner. Eighth US GP: Jack Brabham won, John Surtees fastest lap. Ninth Mexican GP: John Surtees pole, Richie Ginther fastest lap, and John Surtees won. Oh, here we have Richie Ginther having the fastest lap and someone else (John) winning. So both Jim and Richie aren't the only ones because in this row, it's John who won, not Jim. Wait, so in this row, the fastest lap is Richie Ginther, but the winner is John Surtees. So that means Richie had a fastest lap without winning. But the claim says "jim clark and richie ginther be the only driver to have both." So if they didn't both win and have the fastest lap together, then it's false. Wait, actually, the claim says both Jim and Richie are the only ones who have both the fastest lap and won. But in this row, it's just Richie having the fastest lap but someone else (John) winning. So that means the claim is incorrect because there are other drivers besides Jim and Richie who have both. So I think the claim is false. Also, in some rows like the US GP, John Surtees has the fastest lap without winning; no, wait, in US GP, the winner is Jim Clark? Wait, no: looking back at the US row: united states grand prix watkins glen 2 october jack brabham john surtees jim clark lotus - brm f report Wait, so in US GP, the winning driver is Jim Clark? Because "jim clark" is in the fifth column. Wait no: looking at the columns: columns are race, circuit, date, pole position, fastest lap, winning driver, constructor, tyre, report. So for US row: Pole position: Jack Brabham Fastest lap: John Surtees Winning driver: Jim Clark So in this case, Jim won and someone else had the fastest lap. So that's another instance where a driver (Jim) won without having the fastest lap himself. But back to Mexican GP: pole: John Surtees fastest lap: Richie Ginther winner: John Surtees So here, Richie had the fastest lap but didn't win. Jim didn't have either in this row. So the claim that Jim and Richie are the only ones who both won and had the fastest lap is incorrect because in this row, someone else (John) won while Richie had the fastest lap. Therefore, the claim is false. ```json { "answer": "FALSE", "relevant_cells": [ { "row_index": 9, "column_name": "fastest_lap" }, { "row_index": 9, "column_name": "winning_driver" } ] } ```
